text:
Welcome to How To Cook That
I am Ann Reardon

Today we are going to cook raspberry creme
brulee.

To make your sauce take 220g of frozen raspberries
and put 2/3 of them into a saucepan with a

little bit of vanilla extract and a spoonful
of sugar.

Stir over a high heat until the mixture boils
and the raspberries start to fall apart.

Pour this hot mixture into a fine sieve and
using the back of a spoon push through as

much of the liquid as you can. After a few
minutes you will be left with just a slurry

of seeds in the sieve and the sauce in the
bowl.

Place a few of the whole raspberries in the
base of each of your serving dishes and then
spoon over some sauce.

Don't forget to turn on your oven so that
it can heat up and then put your cream in

a saucepan. For quantities used in the is
recipe click on the link in the description

below the video to go to the blog howtocookthat.net
Take a vanilla bean and cut it in half lengthwise.

If you open it up you'll see lots of tiny
black seeds which is what we are after.

Scrape your knife along the full length of
the inside of the bean to get all those seeds

out. And then put the seeds and the pod into
the cream. If you don't have a vanilla bean
you can just use some vanilla extract.

Bring the cream to boil and then remove from
the heat and leave for about 15 minutes for
the flavours to infuse.

Then remove the large pieces of vanilla pod
and reheat your cream.

Whisk together your egg yolks and sugar until
they look nice and thick and pale. Pour a

little bit of the cream at a time to start
with and whisk it well, and then once you've

added some of it you can quickly tip in the
rest.

Pour it through a sieve to get rid of any
of the smaller pieces of vanilla pod that

might have been left behind. When you pour
the mixture into your containers it helps

if you pour it onto a spoon that you're holding
right low down in the container. That helps

disperse the liquid gently onto the raspberry
sauce so that it sits on top of that sauce
instead of mixing it all up together.

Then place them in a heat proof baking dish
and add some water to the dish. If your oven

temp is too hot it can cause the brulee to
split leaving like a curdled custard sitting

in oil. So make sure your oven is at the right
temperature and that the water on the outside

of the bowl comes up to the level of the brulee
on the inside of the bowl.

Brulees cook quite slowly, to check if they
are done take one out and give a gentle shake

side to side. Here this one is not ready yet
because you can see it is still wobbling right
the way to the edges.

20 minutes later and this one is ready. See
the difference it is a bit set around the

edge but it still has a wobble in the middle.
That is what you're looking for.

Take them out of the oven, cool and then chill
them in the fridge.

To make the crispy sugary part on top, put
a thin film of brown sugar over the brulee

and use a brulee torch to melt it. You can
use white sugar but it doesn't melt as easily

or give such a good colour. Make sure you
don't put a heap of sugar into one pile because

then it will be burning before yoiu manage
to melt it. So just put a thin layer of sugar.

If you want a thicker layer of caramel you
can always put a second layer of sugar on
top and repeat the process.

If you don't have a brulee torch then you
can still make this dessert. Put some sugar

into a saucepan in a thin layer and let it
melt. Your heat needs to be on high heat.

And then just pour it over the top. It won't
be as thin as using the blowtorch and won't
be as easy to crack with your spoon.

Brulee is a really rich creamy dessert which
is why I have paired it with the raspberries
sauce at the bottom to give some contrast.

Thanks for clicking like and don't forget
to subscribe for more desserts, sweet snacks,

cake decorating tutorials and chocolate videos.
See you next week.
[music by youtube.com/setsailtv]
